title: Urban Assembly School for Law and Justice
text:
The Urban Assembly School for Law & Justice, often shortened to SLJ, is a small <a href="law">law</a>-themed <a href="college%20preparatory">college preparatory</a> <a href="State%20school">public</a> <a href="high%20school">high school</a> in <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. It is one of a group of 21 high and <a href="middle%20school">middle school</a>s operated by the <a href="Urban%20Assembly">Urban Assembly</a> (a New York City non-profit organization), which do not require <a href="Educational%20entrance%20examination">entrance examinations</a> The school is housed in a courthouse building near the <a href="Brooklyn%20Bridge">Brooklyn Bridge</a>.
SLJ was founded in 2004 with a $400,000 grant from the organization <a href="New%20Visions%20for%20Public%20Schools">New Visions for Public Schools</a>, and support from the <a href="Cravath%2C%20Swaine%20%26amp%3B%20Moore">Cravath, Swaine & Moore</a> law firm. It continues to receive grants from organizations such as the <a href="Robin%20Hood%20Foundation">Robin Hood Foundation</a>. Its structure included a separate foundation, the Adams Street Foundation, "responsible for integrating pre-college enrichment and preparation for college and career into the school’s curriculum" through partnerships with various corporate, foundation and programmatic partners ranging from the <a href="Red%20Hook%20Community%20Justice%20Center">Red Hook Community Justice Center</a> to <a href="CBS%20News">CBS News</a> to the <a href="City%20University%20of%20New%20York">City University of New York</a>.
